are you sure you don't have write tab switched on the USB key?
no switches on the usb key that enable read/write protection?  Otherwise, just as the other gentlemen said, perhaps it's mounted to read-only

just format it using gparted, and select ext3 filesystem (if you plan to use only under linux), or (NTFS/FAT if planning to use in windows as well).  Don't worry about the 'virus' on the usb key.  You're not using windows at the moment.
umount it first, then try one of the utilities to remove the partition
try removing the USB key, confirm there are no read/write tabs on the key, plug it back in, and run a dmesg to check the output
once you plug it back in, if hal mounts the usb device, umount it and try using gparted again
